report:
# Assessment Literacy Collaborative Workgroup Project

## Deliverables (due March 1st)

### February 18th: Share to all with partner edits
### February 26th: Project Completion


1. Assessment Literacy modules/examples.
2. Assessment Literacy Capstone Paper.
3. Assessment Literacy platform paper/module. 



## Assessment Literacy Paper Outline

### Introduction (Damian & Chris) 

1. Context/background problem statement  
2. History/research on state of assessment literacy  
3. Need: Why assessment literacy? 


### Defining Assessment Literacy (Charlie & Jeri)

1. Framework: Data, assessment, measurement. 
2. Assessment Users and Uses  
3. Users: Teachers, administrators (principles, curriculum directors), and policy makers
4. Exemplars/illustrations associated with the different combinations of users and uses.


### Improving Assessment Literacy  (Jeri & Charlie)

1. Formal (pre-service and in-service for teachers and administrators)
2. Informal and ongoing  
3. Via test design and reporting  


### Sustaining and Evaluating Assessment Literacy (Chris & Damian)

1. What needs to be done to sustain assessment literacy efforts.
2. How should assessment literacy initiatives be evaluated.

presentation:
# Are results meaningful?
## Considerations for Drawing Inferences from Aggregate Assessment Results

---

## Introduction

Stakeholders often look to large scale assessment results as a key source of information to support (or reject) policy initiatives.

In this module, we will explore considerations that should accompany inferences from aggregate assessment results.

---

## Limits of Assessment

It is important to understand that assessments are a piece of information that can inform our understanding of student achievement with respect to selected academic content.

Assessment results are not singularly sufficient to support causal claims or identify policy solutions. 

---

## The Broader Research Imperative

To inform our understanding of outcomes, policy makers should regard assessment results as a part of a broader research agenda

---

## Key Questions 

* What is the nature of the claim? 
* What is the strength of the claim? 
* To what extent are the outcomes consistent? 
* To what extent is causal attribution supported?
* Can the claim be falsified? 

---

## What is the nature of the claim?

There are many ways to describe outcomes with assessment results:

* Status: performance indicator from a single administration (e.g. percent proficient on the 3rd grade reading test in 2015)

* Improvement: change in performance for the same measure at different points in time (e.g. difference in percent proficient on the 3rd grade reading test in 2015 compared to 2014)

* Growth: change in performance for a matched cohort of students 

---

## What is the strength of the claim?

How does one know if, for example, improvement of 5% is practically meaningful?

* Statistically significant results indicate that results are most likely not due to chance, but this does not indicate if the magnitude of the finding is large or meaningful
* Effect sizes can provide an indication of the strength of the finding described in standard deviation units
* Examining multiple years of data with comparable measures and populations can provide insight on the degree to which the finding is exceptional

---

## To what extent are outcomes consistent?

Dimensions to consider in analyses

* Unit: e.g. state, district, school, class, subgroup
* Outcome: e.g. status, improvement, growth
* Time: e.g. current year, prior years

The focus is examining the extent to which patterns are consistent across analyses

---

## To what extent is causal attribution supported?

Criteria include:

* Is temporal precedence established?  That is, does x always occur before y? 
* Is there an empirical relationship (e.g. correlation) between the hypothesized cause (x) and the outcome (y)?
* Does manipulation of x influence y? 
* Can rival conjectures (i.e. other possible causes) be ruled out? 
* Are findings consistent with theory and expectation?


---

## Can the claim be falsified?

*  Scientific research must be falsifiable.  For example, to what extent do outcomes differ when the hypothesized cause is not present? 
*  Importantly, it is not correct to claim a proposition is true because there is no evidence that it is false

Absence of evidence is not evidence of absence

---

##  The Big Picture

Assessment results used as part of a research plan that calls upon multiple sources of evidence and is built on a credible theory of action can strengthen our understanding of the factors that contribute to student achievement

This is complicated by the reality that effects often play out differently in various contexts and interact with other factors

report:
# Are results meaningful? 
## Considerations for drawing inferences from summary assessment results

### Introduction
Often education leaders review summary assessment results for the purpose of evaluating programs, practices, or policies.    A district superintendent, for example, may examine school level results from the annual state assessment and consider why the proficiency rates in eighth grade mathematics increased for some schools in her district but were flat for many others.   In such circumstances, it is natural to form hypotheses about the findings.  For example, did the teachers in the schools experiencing the gains implement superior instructional practices compared to other schools?   In fact, it may seem reasonable to take this a step further consider how some tentative explanations could inform policy and practice.  For instance, should other schools adopt the curricular resources or teaching methods used in the more rapidly improving schools?  These are important questions with far-reaching implications.   Accordingly, the purpose of this essay is to review some key considerations to help education leaders determine whether summary assessment results should be used to support broader inferences.      

### Essential Questions

There are three essential questions that can be used to frame an examination of the meaningfulness of summary assessment results.   
-	Is the outcome due to student achievement or something else?
-	Is the magnitude sufficient to be practically important?  
-	What factor(s) influenced the outcome?  

#### Is the outcome due to student achievement?

The first question considers whether the finding is signal or noise.  All assessment results are noisy to some degree due to various sources of error.  One source of error is measurement error.  This refers to the extent to which the test from which the results derive is valid and reliable.  Another source is sampling error.  This refers to the extent to which the group of examinees who took the test can be thought to adequately represent the full population of potential examinees.  The best case to associate a finding with student achievement occurs when:
-	The test has a high degree of validity for the context and claim (e.g. proficiency) that is being examined. 
-	The test has a high degree of precision for this claim.
-	The group of examinees on which the summary result is based is both large and representative of the population.  

Apart from measurement error and sample characteristics, there are a number of practical factors that may threaten a claim that results reflect student achievement.  For example, a claim that student achievement improved due to an annual increase in proficiency rate should be supported by strong evidence that the test is comparable to the form used in the previous year and that testing conditions remain consistent.   The test content may be similar and designed to be parallel across years, but if large numbers of students took the assessment on computer one year and paper the next, this change in mode complicates interpretation that results are due to student achievement alone.  

#### Is the magnitude sufficient to be practically important?  

One can imagine a circumstance in which there is a high degree of confidence that findings are due to shifts in student achievement, but the magnitude of the finding is simply not large enough to be meaningful.  

Often findings are evaluated with respect to ‘statistical significance,’ but this alone is insufficient to address whether the result is meaningful.  Statistical significance simply means the effect is very likely greater than zero in the population.   However, any non-zero value can be statistically significant particularly if the sample on which the result was based is large.  
Effect sizes are a more conventional measure often used to evaluate magnitude.  An effect sizes expresses the outcome (e.g. increase in scale scores) in standard deviation units.     Effect sizes can be evaluated against thresholds based in the literature or from previous practice.  

#### What factor(s) influenced the outcome?  
This question is by far the most challenging, because it relies on some degree of confidence in a causal statement. 

In the best case – and some would say the only case – causal statements can only be supported when results come from a true experimental design.  A true experimental design involves randomly assigning participants into a treatment and control group and manipulating the independent variable.  For example, an experimental design to examine whether student achievement is higher for high schools on a block schedule compared to a traditional schedule, would involve:
-	Randomly assign a group of students to high schools based on schedule type
-	Establish clear and consistent conditions for the implementation of each type of schedule in all schools

Obviously, there are a host of ethical and practical reasons that make this type of study extremely difficult to implement in education.  It is more typical to evaluate assessment outcomes from conditions that occur naturally.  However, when assessment results are reviewed under these natural conditions, it is generally regarded as falling well short of the evidence required to support a causal claim. 

Other questions necessary to consider to support causal inferences include:
-	Is temporal precedence established?  For example, can one be certain that instructional impact occurred prior to improving student achievement as opposed to the gains in student achievement occurring before instruction?  
-	Is there an empirical relationship?  That is, the hypothesized cause is well correlated with the outcome.
-	Does manipulation of the hypothesized cause influence the outcome?  If one factor influences another, it stands to reason that increasing or decreasing that factor should have a corresponding impact on the outcome.  
-	Can rival conjectures be ruled out?  If there are other potential causes, sources of evidence such as those described in this section should be applied to confirm or rule out these hypotheses.
-	Are findings consistent with theory and expectation?  Finally, a causal claim should be consistent with a theory of action that can be well articulated and has a basis in research.  For example, if a particular instructional practice is thought to influence student achievement, that claim is strengthened by an established theory and research base that reveals this is a plausible claim that has been described and explained previously.       

### Sources of Evidence

When evaluating summary assessment results, a reasonable perspective may be to identify noteworthy findings that are good candidates for further examination.  These noteworthy findings become the basis for additional discussion and inquiry.  The following sources of evidence are suggested to provide a basis to identify findings that are more likely to be meaningful and can be prioritized as candidates for follow-up.
-	Findings are consistent across time (e.g. multiple years) 
-	Findings are consistent within or across units (e.g. schools of various types, student subgroups)
-	Magnitude of effect is practically meaningful
-	Findings are not well correlated with factors that should not be related to student achievement (e.g. school size)
-	Findings can be corroborated with other source of trustworthy qualitative or quantitative evidence (e.g. schools with high academic achievement also recognized for accomplished educators)

In sum, drawing inferences from summary assessment results should be based on a pattern of evidence across time which can be corroborated with additional sources.  By so doing, hypothesis can be streamlined, refined, and prioritized, which provides a basis for more in-depth research in support of evidence to support policy or practice.

presentation:
# Basic Literasee ## Mathematics typesetting --- - [Literasee](http://literasee.io) supports math typesetting with [MathJax](https://www.mathjax.org/). - Profesional quality typeset mathematics as part of any web-based content one produces! - Supported in both Report and Presentation formats. - Accessible via standard [LaTeX](https://www.latex-project.org/) markup. --- ## In-line math

* The cube root of $x$ is denoted $\sqrt[3]{x}$.

* In-line summation notation $\sum\_{i=1}^n x\_{i} = x\_1 + x\_2 + \cdots + x\_n$.

* In-line limit notation $\lim\_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2n + 5}{n} = 2$.

--- ## Centered math: * Basic limit notation: $$ \lim\_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2n + 5}{n} = 2 $$ === Stokes Theorem: $$ \int\_{\partial \Omega} = \int\_\Omega d\omega $$ === Three parameter logistic IRT model: $$ p\_i (\theta) = c\_i + {1 - c\_i \over 1 + e^{-a\_i(\theta - b\_i)}} $$
report:
Typesetting Mathematics

[Literasee](http://literasee.io) (via the [marked](https://github.com/chjj/marked) markdown interpreter) includes [MathJax](https://www.mathjax.org/) which enables typeset quality mathematics as part of any web-based content one produces. Mathematics is included via standard [TeX/LaTeX](https://www.latex-project.org/) markup. The examples that follow show how much is possible. As you look at the examples, if you're wondering what the mark-up is that gives a particular result, because Literasee is [GitHub](https://www.github.com) based, you can always look at the [source](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Literasee/basic_mathematics/master/report.md)). ## In-line math: The cube root of $x$ is denoted $\sqrt[3]{x}$. Let $x\_i = i$, then $\sum\_{i=1}^n x\_{i} = x\_1 + x\_2 + \cdots + x\_n = n(n-1)/2$. Using L'Hôpital's rule one can easily show that $\lim\_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2n + 5}{n} = 2$. The Continuum Hypothesis (assuming the Axiom of Choice) can be stated as: $2^{\aleph\_0} = \aleph\_1$. The Cauchy-Schwarz inequality: $\left( \sum_{k=1}^n a\_k b\_k \right)^2 \leq \left( \sum\_{k=1}^n a\_k^2 \right) \left( \sum\_{k=1}^n b\_k^2 \right)$ ## Displaystyle (left- and center-justified) math: #### The Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality $\displaystyle \left( \sum_{k=1}^n a\_k b\_k \right)^2 \leq \left( \sum\_{k=1}^n a\_k^2 \right) \left( \sum\_{k=1}^n b\_k^2 \right)$ #### Basic limit notation: $$ \lim\_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2n + 5}{n} = 2 $$ #### Stokes Theorem: $$ \int\_{\partial \Omega} = \int\_\Omega d\omega $$ #### Three parameter logistic IRT model: $$ p\_i (\theta) = c\_i + {1 - c\_i \over 1 + e^{-a\_i(\theta - b\_i)}} $$ #### A Cross Product Formula $$\mathbf{V}_1 \times \mathbf{V}_2 = \begin{vmatrix} \mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\\\ \frac{\partial X}{\partial u} & \frac{\partial Y}{\partial u} & 0 \\\\ \frac{\partial X}{\partial v} & \frac{\partial Y}{\partial v} & 0 \end{vmatrix} $$ ## Aligned equations: The binomial expansion is given in Equation \eqref{eq:binomial} $\begin{align} f(x, y) & = (x+y)^n \tag{1}\\\\ & = {n \choose 0} x^ny^0+ {n \choose 1} x^{n-1}y^1 + \cdots + {n \choose n} x^0y^n\tag{2} \label{eq:binomial}\\\\ \end{align}$ $\begin{align} MSE(\hat{\theta}) & = \mathbb{E}[(\hat{\theta} - \theta)^2] \\\\ & = \dfrac{1}{n} \sum\limits\_{i=1}^n (\widehat{\theta}\_{i} - \theta\_i)^2 \\\\ \end{align}$ ## Matrices: $\left( \begin{matrix} a & b \\\\ c & d \end{matrix} \right) \left( \begin{matrix} 0 \\\\ 1 \end{matrix} \right) = \left( \begin{matrix} b \\\\ d \end{matrix} \right)$ $\left( \begin{matrix} 1 & 2 & \cdots & 10 \\\\ 2 & 3 & \cdots & 11 \\\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\\\ 10 & 11 & \cdots & 20 \end{matrix} \right)$ ## Conditional equations: $$f(x) = \begin{cases}1 & -1 \le x < 0 \\\\ \frac{1}{2} & x = 0 \\\\ 1 - x^2 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$$ ## Mixtures of inline and centered mathematics: #### Quadratic equation When $a \ne 0$, there are two solutions to the quadratic equation $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$ and they are $$x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}.$$ #### Golden Ratio The _Golden Ratio_ is an irrational number equal to $\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}$. The ratio, often denoted as $\varphi$, can be expressed as a continued fraction as follows: $$\bbox[10px,gold,border:2px solid black]{\textrm{Golden Ratio} \equiv \varphi=1+\cfrac1{1+\cfrac1{1+\cfrac1{1+\cfrac1{1+\ddots}}}}}$$ #### Normal distribution The probability density of the normal distribution with mean $\mu$ and standard deviation $\sigma$, denoted $\mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma)$, is given by: $$ f(x | \mu, \sigma^2) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2 \sigma^2}} $$ #### Dot product Let $\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} \in \mathbb{R}^n$, then the _dot product_ of $\mathbf{x}$ and $\mathbf{y}$ is $$ \mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{y} = \sum\_{i=1}^n x_i y_i. $$ The inner product of a vector $\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n$ with itself, denoted $\lVert x \rVert$, is the squared Euclidean distance associated with $\mathbf{x}$. #### Reference to a previous equation Recall the binomial expansion is given in Equation \eqref{eq:binomial} previously. ## Numerous Math fonts Bulletin Board font: $\mathbb{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ}$ Math bold font: $\mathbf{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz}$ Math typewriter font: $\mathtt{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz}$ Math sans-serif font: $\mathsf{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz}$ Math Roman font: $\mathrm{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz}$ Math calligraphic letters: $\mathcal{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ}$ Math script letters: $\mathscr{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ}$ Math "fraktur" (old German) letters: $\mathfrak{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz}$

description: Basic Markdown for use with Literasee
presentation:
# This is a header
## This is a subheader

---

## This is the second slide

A blank line, then 3 dashes, then another blank line delimit a new slide.

Note: You can create speaker notes by beginning the line with "Note:", like this.

---

## Most Markdown features are supported

report:
# What is Markdown?

[Markdown](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#list) is a simple, lightweight syntax designed by [Jon Gruber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Gruber)
and [Aaron Schwartz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aaron_Swartz) to enable the creation of easy-to-read and easy-to-write
text that can be converted to HTML for web-based rendering. **Content creation on [Literasee](literasee.io) begins with Markdown.**

Markdown supports numerous types of content/text formatting including:

* [Headers](#headers) 
* [Text](#text)
* [Lists](#lists)
* [Tables](#tables)
* [Hypertext links](#hypertext-links)
* [Embedded images](#embedded-images)
* [Embedded videos](#embedded-videos)
* [Blockquotes](#blockquotes)
* [Code & syntax highlighting](#code-syntax-highlighting)
* [Horizontal rules](#horizontal-rules)

---


## Headers

```
# H1 Heading
## H2 Heading
### H3 Heading
#### H4 Heading
##### H5 Heading
###### H6 Heading
```

# H1 Heading

## H2 Heading

### H3 Heading

#### H4 Heading

##### H5 Heading

###### H6 Heading

---


## Text

```
**Bold** or __Bold__
_Italic_ or *Italic*
_**Bold Italic**_ or **_Bold Italic_**
~~strike through~~
```

**Bold** or __Bold__

_Italic_ or *Italic*

_**Bold Italic**_ or **_Bold Italic_**

~~strike through~~

---


## Lists

```
1. First ordered list item
2. Another item
  * Unordered sub-list.
  - Second item of unordered sub-list using minus.
  + Third item of unordered sub-list using plus.
1. Actual numbers don't matter, just that it's a number
  1. Ordered sub-list
  2. Second item of sub-list
4. And another item.

   You can have properly indented paragraphs within list items. Notice the blank line above, and the leading spaces (at least one, but we'll use three here to also align the raw Markdown).

   To have a line break without a paragraph, you will need to use two trailing spaces.  
   Note that this line is separate, but within the same paragraph.  
   (This is contrary to the typical GFM line break behaviour, where trailing spaces are not required.)
```

1. First ordered list item
2. Another item
  * Unordered sub-list.
  - Second item of unordered sub-list using minus.
  + Third item of unordered sub-list using plus.
1. Actual numbers don't matter, just that it's a number
    1. Ordered sub-list
    2. Second item of sub-list
4. And another item.

   You can have properly indented paragraphs within list items. Notice the blank line above, and the leading spaces (at least one, but we'll use three here to also align the raw Markdown).

   To have a line break without a paragraph, you will need to use two trailing spaces.⋅⋅
   Note that this line is separate, but within the same paragraph.⋅⋅
   (This is contrary to the typical GFM line break behaviour, where trailing spaces are not required.)

---

## Tables

You can create tables by assembling a list of words and dividing them with hyphens - (for the first row), 
and then separating each column with a pipe |:

```
First Header  | Second Header
------------- | -------------
Content Cell  | Content Cell
Content Cell  | Content Cell
```

First Header  | Second Header
------------- | -------------
Content Cell  | Content Cell
Content Cell  | Content Cell


To enhance readability, you can also add extra pipes on the ends:

```
| First Header  | Second Header |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
```

| First Header  | Second Header |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |

Note that the dashes at the top don't need to match the length of the header text exactly. Text emphasis is also supported in tables.

```
| Name | Description          |
| ------------- | ----------- |
| Help      | Display the help window.|
| Close     | Closes a window     |
| Email     | Initiate email window |
| ~~Twitter~~   | ~~Tweet~~ |
```

| Name | Description          |
| ------------- | ----------- |
| Help      | Display the help window.|
| Close     | Closes a window     |
| Email     | Initiate email window |
| ~~Twitter~~   | ~~Tweet~~ |

---


## Hypertext links

```
| Markdown | Result |
|----------|--------|
| ```[An inline-style link](http://literasee.io)``` | [An inline-style link](http://literasee.io)|
| ```[An inline-style link with title](http://literasee.io "Literasee Homepage")``` | [An inline-style link with title](http://literasee.io "Literasee Homepage") |
| ```[A reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]``` | [A reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text] |
| ```[A numbered reference-style link][1]``` | [A numbered reference-style link][1] |
| ```[A relative reference to a repository file](../blob/master/LICENSE)``` | [A relative reference to a repository file](../blob/master/LICENSE) |

URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. 
http://www.example.com or <http://www.example.com> and sometimes 
example.com (but not on Github, for example).

Some text to show that the reference links can follow later.

[arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]: https://www.nciea.org
[1]: http://www.nciea.org
```

| Markdown | Result |
|----------|--------|
| ```[An inline-style link](http://literasee.io)``` | [An inline-style link](http://literasee.io)|
| ```[An inline-style link with title](http://literasee.io "Literasee Homepage")``` | [An inline-style link with title](http://literasee.io "Literasee Homepage") |
| ```[A reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]``` | [A reference-style link][Arbitrary case-insensitive reference text] |
| ```[A numbered reference-style link][1]``` | [A numbered reference-style link][1] |
| ```[A relative reference to a repository file](../blob/master/LICENSE)``` | [A relative reference to a repository file](../blob/master/LICENSE) |

URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. 
http://www.example.com or <http://www.example.com> and sometimes 
example.com (but not on Github, for example).

Some text to show that the reference links can follow later.

[arbitrary case-insensitive reference text]: https://www.nciea.org
[1]: http://www.nciea.org

---


## Embedded images

Literasee logo embedded inline and reference (hover to see the title text):

```
Inline-style: 
![alt text](https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/16685371?v=3&s=200 "Literasee logo")

Reference-style: 
![alt text][logo]

[logo]: https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/16685371?v=3&s=200 "Literasee logo"
```

Inline-style: 
![alt text](https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/16685371?v=3&s=200 "Literasee logo")

Reference-style: 
![alt text][logo]

[logo]: https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/16685371?v=3&s=200 "Literasee logo"


---

## Embedded videos

Markdown doesn't directly support the inclusion of videos. However, Markdown
supports HTML which can be used to embed videos

<iframe style=“border: 2px solid #111111;” src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/62604492?color=c9ff23&byline=0&portrait=0" width="800" height="450" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

---

## Blockquotes

```
> Blockquotes are very handy in email to emulate reply text.
> This line is part of the same quote.

Quote break.

> This is a very long line that will still be quoted properly when it wraps. Oh boy let's keep writing to make sure this is long enough to actually wrap for everyone. Oh, you can *put* **Markdown** into a blockquote. 
```

> Blockquotes are very handy in email to emulate reply text.
> This line is part of the same quote.

Quote break.

> This is a very long line that will still be quoted properly when it wraps. Oh boy let's keep writing to make sure this is long enough to actually wrap for everyone. Oh, you can *put* **Markdown** into a blockquote. 

---


## Code & syntax highlighting


```javascript
if (isAwesome){
  return true
}
```


```R
x <- rnorm(100, mean=50, sd=10)
y <- x + rnorm(100)
plot(x, y)
```

## Horizontal rules

```
Three or more...

---

Hyphens

***

Asterisks

___

Underscores
```

Three or more...

---

Hyphens

***

Asterisks

___

Underscores
